awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2022: The role of genomic preadaptation and physiological state in modulating bacterial invasion success
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2022, Integrative Research Investigating the Rules of Life Governing Interactions Between Genomes, Environment and Phenotypes. The fellowship supports research and training of the fellow that will contribute to the area of Rules of Life in innovative ways. In this work, the Fellow will investigate the complex interactions between genetics and the environment that allow a bacterial species to successfully invade a new environment. Bacteria usually fail to invade a host and cause disease, but sometimes they succeed and can cause severe infections when they do. The traits these bacteria have, and conditions which help them achieve this invasion are not well-understood, especially because studies usually only focus on successful invasion without comparing to failed invasions.  The Fellow will quantify invasion success across a diverse set of bacteria isolated from different environments, determine the influence of growth conditions, and develop a machine-learning approaches to link invasion outcomes to genetics. The project aims to predict invasion success in un-tested strains. The Fellow will also broaden participation in science through the recruitment and training of undergraduate students, specifically targeted towards providing equitable access to research opportunities.

This project seeks to better understand the genetic and environmental interactions underlying transitions to pathogenicity by studying the variation in invasion success across strains of the phylogenetically diverse opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa. The Fellow will first determine this variation in invasion outcomes by quantifying the bacteria’s ability to establish in a novel environment containing a competitor species and will assess the role of phylogenetic relatedness and genomic factors in predicting that success. Next, they will quantify the impact of different physiological states, induced by the bacteria’s growth conditions before introduction to their novel environment, on invasion outcomes. Finally, the Fellow will integrate these data to compare general and specific predictive models to quantify the potential for future invasion success in un-tested strains. Throughout the project, the Fellow will gain skills in bacterial genetics, quantifying bacterial traits, and will learn to develop machine learning models to predict phenotypic outcomes from genomic information. In addition to mentoring undergraduate students, the Fellow will engage in scientific outreach aimed at fostering understanding and appreciation for science, with a specific focus on historically underserved institutions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The broad goal of this project was to better understand how generalist bacteria, bacteria that can survive across multiple environments, succeed at invading and establishing within diverse habitats. To address this question, we used Pseudomonas aeruginosa as a model system. P. aeruginosa is a successful bacterial generalist found in many natural and man-made habitats and is also an opportunistic pathogen that causes disease in humans. While the primary goal of this project was to understand bacterial adaptation and generalism, the results are practically relevant for understanding how opportunistic bacterial pathogens adapt to infect humans.

To achieve these goals, we developed a machine learning approach, a type of computer program that learns patterns from data. Specifically, we trained a model to predict the environment a particular strain of P. aeruginosa (an individual group within the species) originated from based solely on its genomic information. We hypothesized that P. aeruginosa adapts to different environments by acquiring or losing specific genes that help it survive in those settings and that these genes would be consistent for each environment. This innovative approach led to six key outcomes, spanning both intellectual merit and broader impacts.

1. Understanding Adaptation Across Strains

By developing a model capable of predicting the environment of a strain based on its genome, we demonstrated that different strains of P. aeruginosa, even those that are not closely related, adapt in similar, predictable ways when exposed to the same environment. While the species as a whole is a generalist (able to survive across many environments), individual strains behave somewhat like specialists (adapted to thrive in specific environments). This finding is significant because it shows that insights gained from studying one strain can help us understand how other strains might behave. Importantly, this knowledge extends beyond P. aeruginosa and informs how other bacteria may adapt to new environments.

2. A Practical Tool for Predicting Environment of Origin

The machine learning model itself is a valuable outcome of this project. It can determine the likely origin of a P. aeruginosa strain, enabling scientists to utilize genomic data that lacks associated environmental context. Furthermore, this approach could be expanded to trace the origins of strains that infect humans, offering insights into the environments where such strains might thrive, and that adaptations that allow them to move into human infection. 

3. Insights into Genes Driving Adaptation

By analyzing the genes used by the machine learning model to make its predictions, we gained insights into how P. aeruginosa adapts to specific environments. For example, when examining strains isolated from the lungs of people with cystic fibrosis, we identified several genes already known to be important for survival in this environment, validating our approach, but also discovered many genes with unknown functions. Since bacteria have numerous genes whose roles remain unclear, our findings provide a prioritized list of hundreds of genes across multiple natural and man-made environments that warrant further study.

4. Understanding Connections Between Environments

We found that some genes important for survival in one environment are also useful in others, suggesting that adapting to one setting might make P. aeruginosa more likely to succesfully invade and thrive in another. This insight helps us understand how natural forces predictably shape the environments where P. aeruginosa (and potentially other bacteria) might succeed.

5. A Framework for Studying Other Generalist Bacteria

This project established an approach that can be applied to study adaptation and generalism in other bacteria beyond P. aeruginosa. By demonstrating the success of this machine learning technique with one species, we have laid the groundwork for studying other species, helping us better understand what factors enable them to survive across multiple environments.

6. Training Future Scientists

Over the course of this project, the principal investigator mentored four Ph.D. students and seven master's students (three of whom have since pursued Ph.D.s). Beyond advancing scientific knowledge, this project provided valuable training opportunities for the next generation of researchers, equipping them with skills in cutting-edge techniques like machine learning and microbial genomics.

Conclusion

In summary, this project has significantly advanced our understanding of how generalist bacteria can adapt to new environments. It has also produced practical tools that can be applied to other bacterial species in future research, all while training future scientists who will continue tackling pressing questions in microbial ecology.
